dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, big tech news this week, uh, Apple is apparently just throwing in the towel on trying to beat Google at its own search game.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple is intensifying long-standing efforts to beat Google at its own game by building its own rival search engine technology, the Financial Times report...

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that headline! Like, they're dismantling their existing search tech, according to the Financial Times. It's kind of a big deal, right?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the latest version of the iPhone operating system, iOS 14, Apple bolstered its own search capabilities with little fanfare, the Financial Times reports.

dialogue_turns.text: It really is. And, get this, it comes after U.S. antitrust regulators are now, like, working *alongside* Google on its deals with other big players, Apple included.

dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] You'd think, wouldn't you? And it ties right into what Apple's been doing. In iOS 14, they scaled back their own search capabilities significantly.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I actually noticed that! Like, when you search from your home screen now, it just, um, funnels you straight to Google.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I actually noticed that! Like, when you search from your home screen now, it just, um, funnels you straight to Google.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The change went largely unnoticed, and included displaying its own search results and linking to websites directly rather than through another engine when users typed queries from their home screens.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Google still gets, what, 8 to 12 billion dollars a year for being the default, and the regulators aren't even investigating *that* deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Google still gets, what, eight to twelve billion dollars a year for being the default, and the regulators aren't even investigating that deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the iPhones default search engine Google, who pay $8-12 billion a year for the privilege in a deal U.S. antitrust regulators are investigating remains unchanged...

dialogue_turns.tts_text: Like what? What are the signs?

dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, it's not just a rumor; there's actual operational evidence backing it up.
